rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.

A number of other significant Cambridge scientists include [[Henry Cavendish]], the discoverer of [[Hydrogen]]; [[Frank Whittle]], co-inventor of the jet engine; [[Lord Kelvin]], who formulated the original [[Laws of Thermodynamics]]; [[William Fox Talbot]], who invented the camera, [[Alfred North Whitehead]], Einstein's major opponent; [[Jagadish Chandra Bose|Sir Jagadish Chandra Bose]], the man dubbed âthe father of radio scienceâ; [[Lord Rayleigh]], one of the most pre-eminent physicists of the 20th century; [[Georges LemaÃ®tre]], who first proposed the [[Big Bang|Big Bang Theory]]; and [[Frederick Sanger]], the last man to win two Nobel prizes.
A number of other significant Cambridge scientists include [[Henry Cavendish]], the discoverer of [[Hydrogen]]; [[Frank Whittle]], co-inventor of the jet engine; [[Lord Kelvin]], who formulated the original [[Laws of Thermodynamics]]; [[William Fox Talbot]], who invented the camera, [[Alfred North Whitehead]], Einstein's major opponent; [[Jagadish Chandra Bose|Sir Jagadish Chandra Bose]], the man dubbed âthe father of radio scienceâ; [[Lord Rayleigh]], one of the most pre-eminent physicists of the 20th century; [[Georges LemaÃ®tre]], who first proposed the [[Big Bang|Big Bang Theory]]; and [[Frederick Sanger]], the last man to win two Nobel prizes.
â
Other Cambridge academics include major economists such as [[John Maynard Keynes]], [[Thomas Malthus]], [[Alfred Marshall]], [[Milton Friedman]], [[Piero Sraffa]] and [[Amartya Sen]], another former Master of Trinity College. [[Image:Wittgenstein1930.jpg|thumb|left|140px|[[Ludwig Wittgenstein]]]] Significant Philosophers [[Desiderius Erasmus]], [[Sir Francis Bacon]], [[Bertrand Russell]], [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]], [[Leo Strauss]], [[George Santayana]], [[Karl Popper|Sir Karl Popper]], [[Allama Iqbal]] and [[G. E. Moore]] were all Cambridge scholars, as were renowned historians such as [[Lord Acton]], [[E. H. Carr]], [[Hugh Trevor-Roper]], [[E. P. Thompson]] and [[Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr.|Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr]].
+
Other Cambridge academics include major economists such as [[John Maynard Keynes]], [[Thomas Malthus]], [[Alfred Marshall]], [[Milton Friedman]], [[Piero Sraffa]] and [[Amartya Sen]], another former Master of Trinity College. Significant Philosophers [[Desiderius Erasmus]], [[Sir Francis Bacon]], [[Bertrand Russell]], [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]], [[Leo Strauss]], [[George Santayana]], [[Karl Popper|Sir Karl Popper]], [[Allama Iqbal]] and [[G. E. Moore]] were all Cambridge scholars, as were renowned historians such as [[Lord Acton]], [[E. H. Carr]], [[Hugh Trevor-Roper]], [[E. P. Thompson]] and [[Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr.|Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr]].
Religious figures at the university have included [[Rowan Williams]], the current [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] and many of his predecessors; [[William Tyndale]]; the early biblical translator responsible for much of the [[Authorized King James Version|King James "Authorised Version"]]; [[William Paley]], the Christian philosopher known primarily for formulating the [[teleological argument]] for the existence of God; [[William Wilberforce]], the man responsible for the [[Abolitionism|abolition]] of the [[slave trade]]; [[John Bainbridge Webster]], a theologian of significant repute; and six winners of the prestigious [[Templeton Prize]], the highest accolade for the study of religion since its foundation in 1972.
Religious figures at the university have included [[Rowan Williams]], the current [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] and many of his predecessors; [[William Tyndale]]; the early biblical translator responsible for much of the [[Authorized King James Version|King James "Authorised Version"]]; [[William Paley]], the Christian philosopher known primarily for formulating the [[teleological argument]] for the existence of God; [[William Wilberforce]], the man responsible for the [[Abolitionism|abolition]] of the [[slave trade]]; [[John Bainbridge Webster]], a theologian of significant repute; and six winners of the prestigious [[Templeton Prize]], the highest accolade for the study of religion since its foundation in 1972.
